newsitem.title: UK: Buyers to take up early pricing for Nigerian crude.
newsitem.headline: Buyers to take up early pricing for Nigerian crude.

text.p: An option to price Nigerian crude oil five days before it loads is likely to be taken up by buyers, oil traders said on Monday.
The option will cost buyers two cents a barrel for crude oil loading in April but because oil prices have recently sunk into contango it should cut the cost of purchases, they said.
Nigerian crude oil is priced against dated Brent which trades against forward Brent prices on the swaps market.
The Contract-For-Differences (CFD) swap market enables oil traders to lock in the value of dated Brent, and therefore Nigerian crude, against forward Brent.
The contango on the value of dated Brent market is roughly 10 cents a week.
This implies a two cents option to price five days early could save a trader around seven cents on a cargo of Nigerian crude.
Nigerian state oil marketer, NNPC, informed customers on Monday that it was cutting the cost of its crude oil in April by between 50 and 87 cents a barrel.
Many customers incurred heavy losses on March loadings due to a sharp fall in the spot value of Nigerian crude.
"This option could be a way of giving back something to the trade after what happened in March. But it does depend on the contango staying in place," said a trader.
